sn22.150:4.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what, do pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn22.150:4.3: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn22.150:4.4: “When form exists, because of grasping form, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.
sn22.150:4.8: consciousness exists, because of grasping form, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.
sn22.150:4.9: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn22.150:4.11: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.150:4.13: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn22.150:4.20: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.150:4.22: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
sn22.150:4.25: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
